image.altText: Brittany Higgins outside court with an inset image of her going through Parliament House security.

props.synopsis: Brittany Higgins tells the Federal Court she tried to "reclaim" the dress she alleges she was sexually assaulted in by wearing it at a Liberal Party function in the months afterwards.

title.children: Brittany Higgins re-wore dress she was allegedly raped in to 'reclaim' it, court hears

image.altText: A photo of a womans chest with a black shirt and jacket

props.synopsis: Two-thirds of Community and Public Sector Union members vote in favour of the latest three-year pay proposal.

title.children: Public servants' union agrees to pay deal, ending negotiation stalemate

image.altText: A group of people holding umbrellas

props.synopsis: Tyrell Edwards, the driver behind the wheel of a car that crashed into a tree in Buxton, killing five teenagers, is sentenced to 12 years behind bars.

title.children: P-plate driver jailed for 12 years over crash that killed five teenagers in Buxton

image.altText: Paul Singer, founder of Elliott Management

props.synopsis: Elliott Management is little-known outside the world of high finance, but throughout its legendary history it's made many enemies, including the Argentine navy. It's now eyeing a stoush with an Australian state over energy.

title.children: Why one of the most feared investors in the world holds the key to an Australian energy crisis

props.synopsis: An AI-based analysis of 20 years of logging by VicForests, shared exclusively with the ABC, shows for the first time, the potential scale of failed regeneration in Victoria's state forests.

title.children: 'It's basically dead': The legacy of decades of logging

image.altText: A car is seen in the left side of a large crowd of Jewish men dressed in black

props.synopsis: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says the homes of two men who shot up a bus stop in Jerusalem on Thursday, killing three people and injuring at least another six, will be "sealed and demolished".

title.children: Homes of shooters in Jerusalem attack to be 'sealed and demolished', Netanyahu says

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: UN officials call for the Kerem Shalom border crossing to be opened to aid
30 Palestinians to be released in exchange for release of 10 hostages in Gaza: Qatari foreign ministry
Six more hostages handed over to Red Cross, Israeli military says

image.altText: Sold sign on Queenslander-style house in a street in Brisbane.

props.synopsis: Property prices are still growing strongly in Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide, but CoreLogic's figures show a slowdown in Sydney and falls for Melbourne and Hobart.

title.children: House prices are 'rocketing along' in a few cities, but starting to fall in others

image.altText: A map showing congested areas in and around the Rozelle Interchange

props.synopsis: The much-discussed Rozelle Interface has proved to have teething problems after opening on Sunday. But experts say it isn't user error.

title.children: Sydney's multi-billion-dollar roadway with choke points designers didn't see coming

image.altText: a white cotton mesh bag with a phone on top showing the green recycle symbol

props.synopsis: How environmentally friendly are the goods you are buying? And how true are the big "green" claims advertisers are making in online ads? New research shows it's easy for marketers to imply their products are "sustainable" without necessarily backing it up.

title.children: New research reveals the greenwashing tricks advertisers use to sell you 'sustainable' products

image.altText: Orthodox Jewish people look at road where a section is blocked off by police

props.synopsis: Hamas's armed wing claims responsibility for an attack that killed at least three people in Jerusalem as they release two more hostages.

title.children: Hamas claims responsibility for attack in Jerusalem

image.altText: A person with pink hair and a colourful skirt in their apartment on a cloudy day

props.synopsis: There are over 200,000 Australians with an autism spectrum condition. But lack of healthcare training and understanding is leaving many of them without quality care.

title.children: Misdiagnosed and gaslit: When autistic Australians go to the doctor, it's often a 'traumatic' experience

image.altText: Peter Dutton smile

props.synopsis: If the government's position doesn't improve substantially, people will take a more serious look at Peter Dutton — the hard man from Queensland — and speculate about what sort of prime minister he'd make, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: What would happen if Dutton managed to win the election? What kind of prime minister would he make?

image.altText: Alaa and his son at the site of their home which has now been reduced to rubble.

props.synopsis: Getting a visitor visa to come to Australia is one thing, getting out of Gaza is another matter entirely. We speak to people inside Gaza who have the visa about the huge challenges they face getting to the Rafa crossing and their relatives here in Australia who are worried sick if they’ll make it alive.

title.children: Alaa and his family have a nine hour walk to exit Gaza. He may need to use bribes for safe passage

image.altText: Mitzi Jonelle Tan, of the Philippines, center, participates in a Fridays for Future protest.

props.synopsis: Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber, the president of the COP28 climate conference in Dubai, says his country, the United Arab Emirates, will chip in $US100 million, a sum matched by Germany. But critics say much more is needed.

title.children: COP28 nations begin climate fund, but experts say it's a paltry sum

image.altText: Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, pictured in front of a dark wooded background, looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: Until a reporter called him last week, Gurpatwant Singh Pannun says he knew nothing about an alleged plot to have him killed. But he says he wasn't shocked to hear he was a target.

title.children: 'I'm ready to face death': Alleged kill plot against New York lawyer tests India-US relations

image.altText: Shane MacGowan performs with The Popes at the Montreux Jazz festival.

props.synopsis: MacGowan, the London-Irish singer-songwriter and frontman of The Pogues, who penned some of the 1980s most haunting ballads before sinking into alcohol and drug addiction, dies.

title.children: Shane MacGowan, hard-drinking frontman of The Pogues, dies at age 65

image.altText: Shoebridge gestures with a hand as he speaks inside the mural hall.

props.synopsis: Amid the continuing conflict in Gaza, Greens spokesman for Defence and Veterans' Affairs David Shoebridge says the government is selling "weapons, after weapons, after weapons" to Israel. RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked David Shoebridge on Australia selling weapons to Israel. Here's what we found

image.altText: Five men in defense uniforms stand on a platform.

props.synopsis: New research reveals the ranks of senior officers in the Australian military has almost doubled over the past twenty years, despite a steady decline in overall numbers.

title.children: Growing number of senior officers in 'top heavy' Australian Defence Force

image.altText: A woman and a man pose in front of a grey backdrop, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Advocates say a large part of the challenge of living with HIV isn't treatment, it's society's deeply ingrained stigma. On World AIDS Day, people living with HIV share what it's like disclosing their status and why it's time for a new narrative.

title.children: 'Will someone still love me?': Advocates say stigma now the scariest part of living with HIV

image.altText: Woman coughing or sneezing into her elbow at her desk with laptop in front of her

props.synopsis: Victoria began its eighth wave of COVID-19 a few weeks ahead of the rest of the nation. Here's what you need to know ahead of Christmas.

title.children: Victoria entered the latest COVID wave early. Its numbers could be promising for the nation

image.altText: A man in combat fatigues with his face painted crouches in bushland, pointing a bullpup rifle.

props.synopsis: Khrys Vignes, 30, died in a Far North Queensland river in 2020 after about 100 bullets were fired during a confrontation with specialist police.

title.children: Police lost control in deadly stand-off with ex-Army reservist, inquest hears

image.altText: A man in casual dress stands in front of a row of flags

props.synopsis: A review recommends overhauling Australia's strongest secrecy law, parts of which have been described as "unnecessary and oppressive".

title.children: Major overhaul recommended for Australia's 'unnecessary and oppressive' secrecy law

image.altText: A small town street looking empty with a long empty road

props.synopsis: A Senate inquiry examining the closure of bank branches in regional Australia is grilling the competition watchdog and financial regulator, while the ASX is lower despite positive data in the US and Europe. Follow live.

title.children: Regulators grilled over regional bank closures, falling inflation in US and Europe suggests end of rate rises, ASX lower

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: All 11 sectors in the red as technology, mining stocks sink ASX
2,100 bank branches closed over past six years, bigger reduction in cities than regions
Senate inquiry into regional bank branch closures grills regulators

image.altText: A firefighter stands on a grassy dune and watches a bushfire's flames.

props.synopsis: The bushfire outlook for summer is warning of a scorching summer. Landowners in rural and urban areas are being urged to prepare their properties for the risk of bushfire.

title.children: A scorching summer is expected, so what can you do to prepare for potential bushfires?

image.altText: James Turner holds up the Australian flag behind his head at the Para-athletics world championships.

props.synopsis: With world titles this year and Olympic medals already in his cabinet, James Turner is looking to smash world records at the 2024 Paris Games.

title.children: Heading into Paris 2024, Australia's top male para-athlete of the year has happy memories in France

image.altText: A side profile of a young boy with glasses with a long red mullet, which is blowing in the wind.

props.synopsis: Queenslander Jayce Bowers, 12, has already won a state title for his meticulously cultivated mane. This weekend he will see how his glorious 'do fares against the very best in the nation and beyond at Mulletfest.

title.children: 12-year-old Queenslander set to go mullet-to-mullet with world's best

image.altText: The video shows Jeffrey McLaughlin holding the boy to the ground.

props.synopsis: The parents of a child restrained by the Tennant Creek mayor during a so-called "citizen's arrest" ask the Northern Territory's major legal service to take action against the mayor.

title.children: Parents want action taken against mayor for 'citizen's arrest' of child, after mayor defends conduct

image.altText: A funeral that shows a tribute and people standing with their head downs

props.synopsis: The son of South Australia's police commissioner has been remembered as a "force of nature" in a touching memorial service, as more than $45,000 is raised for a youth foundation in his honour.

title.children: 'We will love you forever, Charlie boy': SA police commissioner's son farewelled at public twilight service

image.altText: A teenage girl in a white t-shirt and her mother in a black dress sit together outside looking serious.

props.synopsis: A political blame game has ended in the plans for a residential eating disorder centre being shelved indefinitely. The ABC has obtained documents that piece together how it all fell apart.

title.children: Jordynn lives in the one state ditching its plans for a residential eating disorder centre
